Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 07:36AM adenacb wrote: It's very common to have a second surgery to get clear margins...I just had my 2nd, and happily, the margins were clear the 2nd time. My surgeon said they typically start radiation 6 weeks after the surgery.
Posts.Title: Clear Margins tiptop AniPie

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2009 12:30PM adenacb wrote: I think you should be with someone with a medical background when you get your results. It would be best if the doc could be with you to explain them. I wouldn't just read the report all by yourself. Too stressful. Also, you might not understand the results, and then you'd be even more freaked out. Most docs want to tell you once the results are in. Maybe you can make an appointment with the doc once you know they are in? Good luck...
Posts.Title: Waiting for results... mkk050709 mkk050709

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2012 09:27AM adenacb wrote: This is the worst part. As you find out more and more about your particular cancer, and what the options are, you will start to feel better. You will probably have some type of surgery, and then you will have some other treatments as well (chemo, radiation, or medication, for example). As time passes, things will feel more normal: the "new normal." This is definitely the hardest time. Hang in there!
Posts.Title: I don't think I've ever been this sad teeballmom adenacb

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2009 07:50PM adenacb wrote: Beggy, I also found the part about deciding about chemo to be confusing and difficult. I had an onco score of 15. In the end, I decided that I really didn't want to deal with the side effects of chemo. I had radiation and then hormonal therapy, and to add just a bit more, I'm also doing a study that uses ovarian suppression.  Some studies show that ovarian suppression may be what happens with chemo anyway, and that reducing the hormone is what gives women the benefit in terms of recurrence. So I opted for that route. Good luck with your decision. Do what is best for you.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2011 07:32PM adenacb wrote: MDG, I was 47 when I was diagnosed, and my tumor was a bit larger than yours, but otherwise very similar stats. My son was 9 at the time. I remember the chemo decision and discussion to be the most stressful part of the whole BC experience. My onc was pushing for chemo, even after my Oncotype came back in the "low" range.  I really wanted to avoid chemo as nausea is an issue for me. So in the end, my onc agreed with the no chemo. But it was a struggle.  The Oncotype score will help with this decision. You also need to determine, for yourself, if you feel that chemo will benefit you. Apparently the chemo regimens today are much better than they were in the past, and the anti-nausea drugs are much better. So most people get through it okay. Good luck with this decision.
Posts.Title: If you were stage I, did you get chemo??? mdg SusansGarden

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2009 12:13PM adenacb wrote: it sounds like you have some great advice from this group, but I thought I'd chime in. I just finished rads about a month ago. they used the "tattoos" to line me up with the machine each time. I don't think the tattoos had to do with the margins of the radiation treatment at all...it's just to make sure that you are lined up correctly.
Posts.Title: Really worried- questions about margins and tatoos... LoriL LoriL

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2009 07:10PM adenacb wrote: So sorry to hear that you are going through this. First step is to have the surgery (lumpectomy) and see if they can get it all. May have to go in again (re-excise) to get a good "margin" around the lump. Then, as someone else said, you should have a sentinal node biopsy, if they do that procedure where you are, to see if the cancer has spread into the nodes. If it hasn't, you can get the Oncotype Dx test done on your tumor and they will see if you would benefit from chemo. It's a process...take it one step at a time... and good luck.
